I1l. Background of the Program

Statement of Problem

In the post World War || decades, major
changes in shopping habits and population
expansion into the suburbs of our cities have
resulted in the creation of new regional
shopping complexes competing with older
business districts. These shifts were particularly
damaging to central business districts, and in
most major cities a variety of programs have
been initiated to assist these districts in the
difficult process of eliminating blighted sectors,
traffic congestion, parking shortages and in
setting the basis for physical and economic
revitalization.

The smaller established business districts have
also felt the impact of changing shopping
patterns and of population movements but have
not received either the level of concern or the
relative degree of public improvement efforts
that have gone to central areas.

The present circumstances of these centers vary
with relation to such factors as neighborhood
income, accessibility, the strength and
merchandising ability of local merchants and a
number of other factors. Some have been
severely affected by urban blight; others less so.
Some now have a considerable number of
vacant stores; others have maintained
themselves without major economic losses.

Under either condition, there is a need for a
sense of direction with regard to the future.
Virtually no older center can be viewed as well
designed or fully supported by adequate
circulation, parking, public facilities and
amenities.

These conditions have led to periodic demands
from the merchants of individual centers for
additional parking, improved lighting, better
trash collection and similar services. To the
degree that they can make their voices heard in
the inner circles of city government, when
funds are available and there is no organized
opposition to their proposals, some
improvements are made. However, these
isolated improvements are of limited value and
are far short of the general level of
improvement needed by these centers.

The problem is, therefore, to define what is
needed and to establish a program that would

permit those needs to be met over a period of
time.

Sponsorship of study

This study originated in Baltimore out of the
concern of the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on
Small Business about the need for a program of
improving the older centers and safeguarding
the future of small business operations in these
centers against increasing competition. The first
work undertaken in examining the centers and
their neighborhoods and their shopping
potentialities was carried out under Baltimore's
Community Renewal Program studies.

The sponsorship of this Demonstration Study
by the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on Small
Business was particularly advantageous since it
permitted a thorough review and discussion of
proposals without committing the planning and
urban renewal agencies of the City to official
action on any specific plan.

Representatives of Baltimore's Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency and the Department of
Planning were on the project’s Advisory Board
and the work of these agencies was utilized
during the course of this study.

The Study Areas

The Mayor'’s Advisory Commlttee on Small
Business recommended the study areas after
examining 17 older community shopping
centers, all located outside the central business
district. The three areas chosen for the study
were:

Light Street:

Located south of the central business district
near the Port of Baltimore, it serves a
blue-collar population and contains some
aggressive and moderately successful stores. The
shopping area is on a heavily travelled route
between the central business district and the
port area.

Monument Street:

A basically sound commercial strip located east
of the central business district. Although
deterioration is not yet serious, the businesses
serving the low- to moderate-income pOpulatlon
of the area are not thriving.

Pennsylvania Avenue:
A commercial strip cutting diagonally across

several blocks northwest of the central business
district. It contains areas of severe blight arid
has major traffic problems. The upper end of
the strip is a concentrated and active shopping
area and has been described as the center of the
Baltimore ghetto.

The three centers are typical of many older
shopping areas in cities throughout the United
States. Historically, they were important as
satellite cores which developed on the outskirts
of the growing city. All three centers were
actively developed between 1800 and 1880.

Today, the shopping areas are small centers in a
large region. Baltimore is the center of a
five-county region. Its downtown area is both
the center of Baltimore and to a lesser extent of
the entire region. The three areas under study
are among six such shopping areas in the city
containing public markets. The three shopping
areas are centers of communities which, for
purposes of study, are delineated as trade areas.
It is to these shopping areas that most residents
in the surrounding community come to
purchase food, drugs, furniture and clothing.

- While the three trade areas overlap with trade

areas of other neighborhood shopping areas, the
majority of shoppers originate from a slightly
smaller trade area, determined by a 15-minute
walking distance. All three centers are served by
public transportation and transfer points where
change of mode, transportation and direction
can be made.

In general, these procedures were successfully
followed and programs were formulated for the
three areas with a fair amount of agreement.
However, in the the process of following the
procedure, it became apparent that a number of
faulty assumptions were made. The study
resulted in a number of conclusions, separate
and apart from the design solutions, which are
considered to be particularly relevant to any
future work in this field.

As a matter of record the report describes the
methodology followed, the ultimate concepts
and the proposed solutions which are relevant
and appropriate. This is supplemented with
some observations and suggestions for various
approaches which would be more conductive to
the development of appropriate programs and
plans in this type of area in the future.
